long_questions.stem: A 62-year-old man undergoes colectomy for colon cancer. The tumor forms glands resembling colonic mucosa, with only mild atypia and low mitotic activity. Which term best applies?
long_questions.explanation: Well-differentiated tumors closely resemble normal tissue. Poorly differentiated tumors have little resemblance to tissue of origin.

long_questions.stem: A 50-year-old man presents with a rapidly enlarging neck mass. Histology shows sheets of undifferentiated malignant cells with giant cells, necrosis, and numerous mitoses. Which thyroid carcinoma is most likely?
long_questions.explanation: Anaplastic carcinoma is highly aggressive, undifferentiated, with giant cells and poor prognosis.

long_questions.stem: A 59-year-old woman with colon carcinoma undergoes resection. Histology shows malignant glands with marked atypia, little resemblance to colonic mucosa, and frequent mitoses. Which is the best description?
long_questions.explanation: Poorly differentiated adenocarcinomas show little resemblance to normal tissue and have aggressive features.

long_questions.stem: A 42-year-old man undergoes cystoscopy for hematuria. A papillary lesion is excised and histology shows fibrovascular cores lined by normal-appearing urothelium, with an intact basement membrane. What is the best diagnosis?
long_questions.explanation: Papilloma is benign: orderly architecture and intact basement membrane. CIS is flat with marked atypia. Invasive carcinoma breaches the basement membrane.

long_questions.stem: A 36-year-old woman has a cervical lesion. Biopsy reveals full-thickness epithelial atypia with loss of polarity and increased mitoses, but the basement membrane is intact. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
long_questions.explanation: Carcinoma in situ involves full-thickness atypia without invasion past the basement membrane. Dysplasia is partial thickness.

long_questions.stem: A 46-year-old woman undergoes biopsy of a cervical lesion. Atypical cells are confined to the lower third of the squamous epithelium. The basement membrane is intact. Which of the following best describes this lesion?
long_questions.explanation: Mild dysplasia involves atypia in the lower third of the epithelium. CIS involves full thickness atypia.

long_questions.stem: A 70-year-old man has a gastric tumor that appears well circumscribed and encapsulated. Histology shows uniform cells with little atypia and no necrosis. Which is the best classification?
long_questions.explanation: Benign tumors are well circumscribed, encapsulated, and lack cytologic atypia or necrosis.

long_questions.stem: A 65-year-old woman undergoes biopsy of an esophageal lesion. Histology shows disordered squamous epithelium with atypia confined to the middle third of the epithelium. Which diagnosis is most likely?
long_questions.explanation: Moderate dysplasia involves atypia in the lower two-thirds of the epithelium. Severe dysplasia involves almost full thickness atypia.

long_questions.stem: A 72-year-old woman undergoes biopsy of a vulvar lesion. Histology shows full-thickness squamous atypia with mitotic figures, intact basement membrane. Which best describes this lesion?
long_questions.explanation: Carcinoma in situ = full-thickness atypia without invasion past the basement membrane.

long_questions.stem: A 55-year-old woman presents with abdominal fullness and postmenopausal bleeding. Imaging reveals a large uterine mass. Biopsy shows spindle cells with marked nuclear pleomorphism, frequent mitoses, and tumor necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
long_questions.explanation: Leiomyosarcoma is malignant: high mitotic activity, necrosis, and nuclear pleomorphism. Leiomyomas are benign, lack atypia, and are well-circumscribed.

long_questions.stem: A 62-year-old man with prostate carcinoma undergoes resection. Histology shows back-to-back malignant glands with nuclear atypia and frequent mitoses. The basement membrane is breached. Which best describes the diagnosis?
long_questions.explanation: Invasive carcinoma breaches the basement membrane, unlike carcinoma in situ.

long_questions.stem: A 70-year-old man with hepatocellular carcinoma is found to have tumor thrombus in the hepatic vein extending into the inferior vena cava. Which is the most likely route of spread?
long_questions.explanation: Hepatocellular carcinoma commonly spreads hematogenously via hepatic veins to the lungs.

long_questions.stem: A 73-year-old woman with ovarian carcinoma presents with abdominal distention. CT scan shows multiple peritoneal implants. Which mechanism of spread is most likely?
long_questions.explanation: Ovarian carcinomas frequently metastasize by seeding the peritoneum.

long_questions.stem: A 51-year-old man with a lung carcinoma presents with seizures. Brain MRI shows multiple ring-enhancing lesions. Which is the most likely route of metastasis?
long_questions.explanation: Lung carcinomas often spread hematogenously to the brain, adrenal glands, and bone.

long_questions.stem: A 60-year-old woman with breast carcinoma develops enlarged axillary lymph nodes. Biopsy confirms metastatic carcinoma. What route of spread is most likely?
long_questions.explanation: Carcinomas commonly spread via lymphatics, as in breast cancer metastasis to axillary nodes.

long_questions.stem: A 55-year-old man with renal cell carcinoma is found to have a lytic lesion in the femur. What route of metastasis explains this finding?
long_questions.explanation: Renal cell carcinoma commonly metastasizes hematogenously to bone and lung.

long_questions.stem: A 48-year-old man with chronic hepatitis develops a liver mass. Histology shows trabeculae of malignant hepatocytes invading portal tracts and sinusoids. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
long_questions.explanation: Hepatocellular carcinoma arises in cirrhosis and shows malignant hepatocytes invading hepatic structures.

long_questions.stem: A 40-year-old man with multiple café-au-lait spots, axillary freckling, and cutaneous neurofibromas is found to carry a mutation in NF1. Which pathway is dysregulated?
long_questions.explanation: NF1 is a tumor suppressor gene that negatively regulates RAS/MAPK signaling. Loss leads to uncontrolled proliferation.

long_questions.stem: A 12-year-old boy presents with bilateral renal cell carcinoma. Genetic testing reveals a germline mutation in VHL. Which cellular process is most directly dysregulated?
long_questions.explanation: VHL normally regulates degradation of HIF-1α. Mutation leads to ↑ HIF → angiogenesis and tumorigenesis.

long_questions.stem: A 41-year-old woman with family history of thyroid cancer is found to carry a RET mutation. Which syndrome does this most likely represent?
long_questions.explanation: RET proto-oncogene mutations cause MEN2 syndromes (medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, parathyroid hyperplasia or mucosal neuromas).

long_questions.stem: A 33-year-old man with a family history of thyroid nodules and mucosal neuromas is diagnosed with medullary thyroid carcinoma. Which mutation is most likely?
long_questions.explanation: MEN2B due to RET mutations → medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus.

long_questions.stem: A 48-year-old man with a family history of hamartomatous polyps and macrocephaly is found to carry a PTEN mutation. What syndrome does this represent?
long_questions.explanation: Cowden syndrome (PTEN mutation) involves hamartomas, macrocephaly, and ↑ breast, thyroid, endometrial cancers.

long_questions.stem: A 19-year-old boy presents with café-au-lait spots and bilateral vestibular schwannomas. Which mutation is responsible?
long_questions.explanation: NF2 mutation → bilateral vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, ependymomas.

long_questions.stem: A 54-year-old man with a family history of colon and endometrial cancers is diagnosed with right-sided colon cancer. Genetic testing reveals an MSH2 mutation. Which syndrome does this represent?
long_questions.explanation: Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) involves germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes (MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2). Associated with CRC, endometrial, ovarian cancers.

long_questions.stem: A 58-year-old woman with breast carcinoma undergoes genetic testing. A pathogenic CHEK2 mutation is identified. What is the function of this gene?
long_questions.explanation: CHEK2 encodes a checkpoint kinase important for DNA damage signaling and repair.

long_questions.stem: A 46-year-old woman presents with colon cancer. Genetic testing shows MSI-H. Which therapeutic approach may be most effective?
long_questions.explanation: MSI-H tumors (e.g., Lynch syndrome) often respond well to immune checkpoint blockade.

long_questions.stem: A 27-year-old man presents with hundreds of colonic polyps on colonoscopy. Genetic testing reveals a germline mutation in APC. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
long_questions.explanation: FAP (APC mutation) carries near 100% risk of colon cancer, requiring prophylactic colectomy.

long_questions.stem: A 37-year-old man presents with mucocutaneous pigmentation and hamartomatous polyps in the small intestine. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in STK11. What syndrome does he have?
long_questions.explanation: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome: hamartomatous polyps + mucocutaneous pigmentation. STK11 mutation, ↑ risk GI and pancreatic cancers.

long_questions.stem: A 25-year-old man presents with jaw osteomas, epidermoid cysts, and numerous colonic polyps. Which hereditary syndrome is most consistent?
long_questions.explanation: Gardner variant of FAP includes APC mutation with colonic polyps, osteomas, epidermoid cysts, and dental abnormalities.

long_questions.stem: A 45-year-old woman with early-onset breast cancer is found to carry a TP53 mutation. What is her syndrome called?
long_questions.explanation: Li-Fraumeni syndrome: germline TP53 mutation → breast, sarcomas, brain tumors, leukemias, adrenocortical carcinoma.

long_questions.stem: A 60-year-old woman presents with multiple basal cell carcinomas. She is found to carry a PTCH1 mutation. Which pathway is dysregulated?
long_questions.explanation: PTCH1 mutations cause Gorlin syndrome (nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome), linked to abnormal Hedgehog signaling.

long_questions.stem: A 45-year-old man with multiple endocrine tumors is found to carry a MEN1 mutation. Which protein is defective?
long_questions.explanation: MEN1 gene encodes menin, a tumor suppressor. Loss predisposes to pituitary, pancreatic, and parathyroid tumors.

long_questions.stem: A 32-year-old woman with a strong family history of breast cancer undergoes genetic testing and is found to carry a pathogenic BRCA1 mutation. Which mechanism underlies her increased cancer risk?
long_questions.explanation: BRCA1/2 mutations impair homologous recombination DNA repair, predisposing to breast, ovarian, prostate, and pancreatic cancers.

long_questions.stem: A 35-year-old woman presents with ovarian cancer. Her family history includes multiple relatives with breast cancer. Genetic testing reveals a PALB2 mutation. Which pathway is impaired?
long_questions.explanation: PALB2 works with BRCA2 in homologous recombination repair. Mutations predispose to breast, ovarian, pancreatic cancers.

long_questions.explanation: Triploidy often results from dispermy (fertilization of one ovum by two sperm).

long_questions.stem: A cytogenetic study shows multiple double minute chromosomes in a sarcoma. Which phenomenon does this represent?
long_questions.explanation: Double minutes are extrachromosomal DNA fragments indicating gene amplification (e.g., MYCN, MDM2).

long_questions.stem: A newborn presents with micrognathia, webbed neck, lymphedema of hands/feet, and a wide chest. Karyotype reveals 45,X. Which complication is most likely in adolescence?

options.C: Excess estrogen leading to early puberty

long_questions.explanation: Turner syndrome (45,X) → streak ovaries, infertility, short stature, and risk of coarctation of the aorta.

long_questions.stem: A 2-day-old infant is noted to have hypotonia, a flat nasal bridge, upslanting palpebral fissures, a single palmar crease, and a systolic murmur. Karyotype shows 47,XX,+21. Which of the following complications is most likely to develop later in life?
long_questions.explanation: Down syndrome (trisomy 21) is associated with congenital heart disease, intellectual disability, early-onset Alzheimer-like changes, and increased risk of acute leukemias.

long_questions.stem: A 17-year-old boy presents with tall stature, gynecomastia, small testes, and infertility. Karyotype shows 47,XXY. What syndrome does he have?
long_questions.explanation: Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) presents with tall stature, gynecomastia, small testes, infertility, and increased risk of breast cancer.

long_questions.stem: A 14-year-old boy has tall stature, acne, and aggressive behavior. Karyotype shows 47,XYY. Which of the following is correct?

options.C: Increased risk of learning difficulties and behavioral problems

long_questions.explanation: 47,XYY males may be tall with acne and learning/behavioral difficulties, but are usually fertile.

long_questions.explanation: Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18) presents with clenched fists, rocker-bottom feet, congenital heart disease, and severe intellectual disability.

long_questions.stem: A patient with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) undergoes karyotype analysis. The abnormality is t(15;17). Which therapy specifically targets this translocation?
long_questions.explanation: t(15;17) in APL produces PML-RARA fusion protein, treated with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA).

long_questions.stem: A neonate cries with a high-pitched cat-like cry and is noted to have microcephaly, hypertelorism, and severe intellectual disability. Karyotype reveals a deletion in 5p. Which syndrome is this?
long_questions.explanation: Cri-du-chat syndrome results from a deletion in chromosome 5p, characterized by cat-like cry and severe intellectual disability.

long_questions.stem: A newborn with congenital heart defects, hypocalcemia, and recurrent infections is diagnosed with DiGeorge syndrome. Which chromosomal abnormality is present?
long_questions.explanation: DiGeorge syndrome is caused by 22q11 deletion, leading to thymic aplasia, hypocalcemia, and cardiac outflow tract defects.

long_questions.stem: A 6-year-old boy has severe obesity, hypotonia, hypogonadism, and intellectual disability. Genetic testing shows a paternal deletion of 15q11. What syndrome is this?
long_questions.explanation: Prader-Willi syndrome results from loss of paternal allele (15q11). Features include hypotonia, obesity, hypogonadism, and intellectual disability.

long_questions.stem: A 6-year-old girl presents with seizures, inappropriate laughter, ataxia, and intellectual disability. Genetic testing shows a maternal deletion of 15q11. Which syndrome is this?
long_questions.explanation: Angelman syndrome results from loss of maternal allele (15q11). Features include seizures, ataxia, severe ID, and happy puppet laughter.

long_questions.stem: A 4-year-old girl has elfin facies, friendly personality, supravalvular aortic stenosis, and intellectual disability. FISH testing reveals a deletion on chromosome 7q11. Which diagnosis is correct?
long_questions.explanation: Williams syndrome (7q11 deletion) → elfin facies, friendliness, cardiovascular disease, intellectual disability.

long_questions.stem: A newborn presents with partial trisomy due to an unbalanced translocation. Which of the following best describes this cytogenetic abnormality?

options.B: Gain of a segment due to translocation

long_questions.explanation: Partial trisomy results from gain of a chromosome segment due to unbalanced translocation.

long_questions.stem: A 55-year-old man with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with chronic cough and weight loss. Imaging shows a lung mass. Which carcinogen in cigarette smoke most directly contributes to the DNA mutations leading to lung cancer?
long_questions.explanation: Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons in cigarette smoke are potent mutagens responsible for lung cancer development.

long_questions.stem: A 45-year-old woman presents with a liver mass. She lives in a region with high exposure to Aspergillus-contaminated grains. Which genetic change is most likely in her tumor?
long_questions.explanation: Aflatoxin B1 exposure leads to hepatocellular carcinoma via p53 mutations.

long_questions.stem: A 62-year-old man presents with hematuria. He has a history of occupational exposure to aniline dyes. Which cancer is he at risk for?
long_questions.explanation: Aniline dye exposure is strongly linked to transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder.

long_questions.stem: A 30-year-old man from Japan presents with abdominal pain and weight loss. Endoscopy reveals a gastric mass. He reports eating large quantities of smoked fish and pickled vegetables. Which carcinogen is implicated?
long_questions.explanation: Nitrosamines from smoked foods are linked to gastric carcinoma, especially in Japan.

long_questions.stem: A 50-year-old man with chronic arsenic exposure from contaminated well water presents with skin hyperpigmentation and multiple skin nodules. Which cancer is most strongly associated?
long_questions.explanation: Arsenic exposure predisposes to squamous cell carcinoma of skin and lung cancer.

long_questions.stem: A 47-year-old man presents with jaundice and hepatomegaly. He has a long history of vinyl chloride exposure in a plastics factory. Which malignancy is he predisposed to?
long_questions.explanation: Vinyl chloride is associated with hepatic angiosarcoma, a rare vascular tumor.

long_questions.stem: A 40-year-old uranium miner presents with progressive shortness of breath. Chest CT shows multiple pulmonary nodules. Which carcinogen is most strongly implicated?
long_questions.explanation: Radon exposure from uranium mining increases risk of lung cancer.

long_questions.stem: A 70-year-old construction worker with a history of asbestos exposure presents with dyspnea. Imaging reveals diffuse pleural thickening. Which cancer is most likely?
long_questions.explanation: Asbestos exposure is strongly linked to malignant mesothelioma of pleura.

long_questions.stem: A 62-year-old man with chronic benzene exposure at work presents with pancytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy reveals blasts. Which malignancy is he at risk for?
long_questions.explanation: Benzene exposure is linked to acute myeloid leukemia due to bone marrow toxicity.

long_questions.stem: A 50-year-old farmer presents with hepatomegaly. He reports chronic consumption of foods contaminated with Aspergillus flavus. Which mutation is most likely in his hepatocellular carcinoma?
long_questions.explanation: Aflatoxin B1 exposure leads to characteristic p53 mutations in hepatocellular carcinoma.

long_questions.stem: A 45-year-old man who has smoked for 20 years presents with hematuria. Cystoscopy shows a bladder mass. Exposure to which compound in cigarettes most likely caused this?
long_questions.explanation: β-naphthylamine, found in cigarette smoke, is linked to urothelial carcinoma.

long_questions.stem: A 52-year-old woman presents with a breast mass. She has never smoked or used alcohol but has received multiple cycles of chemotherapy in the past. Which secondary malignancy is she at risk for?
long_questions.explanation: Chemotherapy agents, especially alkylating agents, predispose to therapy-related AML.

long_questions.stem: A 61-year-old man presents with dysphagia and weight loss. He has a history of smoking and alcohol use. Esophageal biopsy reveals squamous cell carcinoma. Which synergistic effect contributed to his cancer risk?
long_questions.explanation: Alcohol and smoking synergistically increase risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

long_questions.stem: A 30-year-old woman presents with a cervical lesion. Biopsy shows dysplastic squamous epithelium with koilocytosis. Which viral infection is responsible?
long_questions.explanation: HPV 16/18 cause cervical cancer through E6 and E7 proteins, which inactivate p53 and Rb.

long_questions.stem: A 48-year-old man from China presents with a nasopharyngeal mass. Biopsy shows poorly differentiated carcinoma with lymphoid stroma. Which viral infection is most likely responsible?
long_questions.explanation: EBV is linked to nasopharyngeal carcinoma, especially in southern China.

long_questions.stem: A 55-year-old man with hepatocellular carcinoma is positive for HBsAg. Which viral protein is implicated in oncogenesis?
long_questions.explanation: HBV promotes oncogenesis through HBx protein, which interferes with p53 and enhances growth.

long_questions.stem: A 44-year-old woman presents with a T-cell leukemia/lymphoma. Which virus is implicated?
long_questions.explanation: HTLV-1 is linked to adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma in endemic regions (Japan, Caribbean).

long_questions.stem: A 48-year-old man presents with fever, night sweats, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Biopsy shows Reed-Sternberg cells. Which infectious agent is most associated?
long_questions.explanation: EBV is associated with Hodgkin lymphoma (especially mixed cellularity type).

long_questions.stem: A 40-year-old woman presents with a thyroid nodule. She has a history of childhood radiation therapy for acne. Which type of thyroid cancer is she at increased risk for?
long_questions.explanation: Radiation exposure increases risk of papillary thyroid carcinoma, which shows Orphan Annie nuclei and psammoma bodies.

long_questions.stem: A 5-year-old boy presents with self-mutilating behavior, gout, and choreoathetosis. Genetic analysis reveals a deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). Which metabolite is most elevated in this condition?
long_questions.explanation: HGPRT deficiency (Lesch-Nyhan syndrome) leads to purine salvage failure, increased PRPP, overproduction of uric acid, and neurologic dysfunction.

long_questions.stem: A 10-year-old boy presents with gout and severe neurobehavioral problems. Which inheritance pattern is seen in his condition?
long_questions.explanation: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome (HGPRT deficiency) is X-linked recessive.

long_questions.stem: A 2-year-old boy presents with recurrent infections, failure to thrive, and severe lymphopenia. Genetic testing shows a deficiency in adenosine deaminase (ADA). What is the consequence of this defect?
long_questions.explanation: ADA deficiency → accumulation of dATP, which inhibits ribonucleotide reductase, blocking DNA synthesis → severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

long_questions.stem: A 28-year-old man presents with recurrent infections. Genetic testing shows a deficiency in ribonucleotide reductase. Which process is impaired?

options.D: Conversion of GMP to uric acid

long_questions.explanation: Ribonucleotide reductase converts ribonucleotides (NDPs) to deoxyribonucleotides (dNDPs) for DNA synthesis.

long_questions.stem: A 45-year-old man with chronic gout is started on allopurinol. Which drug should be used with caution due to increased toxicity when combined with allopurinol?

long_questions.stem: A 34-year-old man presents with nephrolithiasis due to uric acid stones. Which drug reduces uric acid production by inhibiting xanthine oxidase?

long_questions.stem: A 55-year-old man with colon cancer is found to have a KRAS mutation. Which hallmark of cancer does this mutation most directly promote?
long_questions.explanation: KRAS mutations lead to constitutive activation of growth signaling pathways, driving uncontrolled proliferation.

long_questions.stem: A 40-year-old woman with breast cancer is found to have loss of p53 function. Which hallmark of cancer is most affected?
long_questions.explanation: Loss of p53 causes genomic instability by impairing DNA repair and apoptosis, allowing accumulation of mutations.

long_questions.stem: A 65-year-old man with chronic myelogenous leukemia has the Philadelphia chromosome. Which hallmark of cancer does this primarily illustrate?
long_questions.explanation: BCR-ABL fusion protein is a constitutively active tyrosine kinase that promotes sustained proliferative signaling.

long_questions.stem: A 50-year-old woman with breast cancer is treated with a CDK4/6 inhibitor. Which hallmark of cancer does this therapy target?
long_questions.explanation: CDK4/6 inhibitors prevent Rb phosphorylation, enforcing the G1/S checkpoint and restoring growth suppression.

long_questions.stem: A 60-year-old man with melanoma responds well to immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy. Which hallmark of cancer is being overcome?
long_questions.explanation: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (anti-PD-1, anti-CTLA-4) restore T-cell activity, overcoming immune evasion by tumor cells.

long_questions.stem: A 55-year-old woman with glioblastoma is treated with bevacizumab. Which hallmark of cancer does this therapy target?
long_questions.explanation: Bevacizumab blocks VEGF signaling, targeting tumor-induced angiogenesis.

long_questions.stem: A 45-year-old woman with ovarian cancer has telomerase activation. Which hallmark of cancer does this represent?
long_questions.explanation: Telomerase activation maintains telomere length, allowing limitless replicative potential.

long_questions.stem: A 50-year-old man with small cell lung cancer exhibits high BCL2 expression. Which hallmark of cancer is represented?
long_questions.explanation: BCL2 overexpression prevents apoptosis by blocking mitochondrial cytochrome c release.

long_questions.stem: A 60-year-old woman with breast cancer develops cachexia. Which mechanism best explains this phenomenon?
long_questions.explanation: Cachexia is mediated by cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1) promoting catabolism and muscle wasting.

long_questions.stem: A 48-year-old man with colon cancer demonstrates the Warburg effect. Which metabolic change is seen?
long_questions.explanation: The Warburg effect is a shift toward aerobic glycolysis, producing lactate even in the presence of oxygen.

long_questions.stem: A 42-year-old woman with cervical cancer due to HPV infection has E6 and E7 viral proteins. Which hallmark is represented?
long_questions.explanation: HPV E6 inactivates p53 and E7 inactivates Rb, allowing cells to bypass growth suppression.

long_questions.stem: A 65-year-old man with pancreatic cancer develops extensive liver metastases. Which hallmark of cancer is this an example of?
long_questions.explanation: Spread to distant organs represents activation of invasion and metastasis.

long_questions.stem: A 70-year-old man with prostate cancer is found to have loss of PTEN. Which hallmark of cancer is promoted by PTEN loss?
long_questions.explanation: PTEN loss enhances PI3K/AKT signaling, promoting sustained proliferative signaling.

long_questions.stem: A 55-year-old woman with melanoma responds poorly to anti-PD-1 therapy due to lack of T-cell infiltration. Which immune phenomenon explains this resistance?
long_questions.explanation: Immune ignorance occurs when T-cells do not infiltrate the tumor, leading to resistance to checkpoint inhibitors.

long_questions.stem: A 64-year-old man with glioblastoma develops mutations in IDH1, leading to accumulation of 2-hydroxyglutarate. Which hallmark of cancer does this represent?
long_questions.explanation: Mutated IDH alters metabolism, producing oncometabolites that contribute to cancer progression.

long_questions.stem: A 50-year-old woman with ovarian cancer receives a PARP inhibitor. This drug exploits which hallmark of cancer?
long_questions.explanation: PARP inhibitors target tumor cells with homologous recombination repair deficiency (e.g., BRCA mutations).

long_questions.stem: A 70-year-old man with hepatocellular carcinoma has increased VEGF expression. Which hallmark of cancer does this promote?
long_questions.explanation: VEGF stimulates angiogenesis, providing blood supply for tumor growth.

long_questions.stem: A 48-year-old man with non-small cell lung cancer receives osimertinib for EGFR mutation. Which hallmark of cancer is being targeted?
long_questions.explanation: EGFR inhibitors block sustained proliferative signaling in EGFR-mutated tumors.

long_questions.stem: A 55-year-old man with pancreatic cancer has mutations in SMAD4. Which hallmark of cancer is most directly impaired?
long_questions.explanation: SMAD4 is part of the TGF-β pathway, which normally suppresses growth. Mutation allows evasion of growth suppression.

long_questions.stem: A 62-year-old woman with breast cancer has overexpression of GLUT1 transporters. Which hallmark of cancer is this most consistent with?
long_questions.explanation: Overexpression of glucose transporters reflects metabolic reprogramming (Warburg effect).

long_questions.stem: A 55-year-old woman with breast cancer undergoes genomic testing with Oncotype DX. Which is the primary purpose of this test?
long_questions.explanation: Oncotype DX evaluates gene expression to estimate recurrence risk and benefit from chemotherapy.

long_questions.stem: A 45-year-old man with metastatic melanoma undergoes testing for PD-L1 expression. Why is this test performed?
long_questions.explanation: PD-L1 testing stratifies patients for immunotherapy, as high expression correlates with response to checkpoint inhibitors.

long_questions.stem: A 35-year-old woman with ovarian cancer undergoes genetic testing for BRCA mutations. How would this result influence therapy?
long_questions.explanation: BRCA-mutated tumors have homologous recombination repair deficiency and respond well to PARP inhibitors.

long_questions.stem: A 50-year-old man with colon cancer is treated with 5-FU and develops severe toxicity. Genetic testing reveals DPD deficiency. What explains this reaction?
long_questions.explanation: Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPD) deficiency prevents catabolism of 5-FU, causing severe toxicity.

long_questions.stem: A 48-year-old man with colon cancer undergoes pharmacogenomic testing. He is found to have UGT1A1 polymorphism. Which chemotherapy drug requires dose adjustment?
long_questions.explanation: UGT1A1 polymorphisms impair irinotecan metabolism, increasing risk of neutropenia and diarrhea.

long_questions.stem: A 60-year-old woman with breast cancer tests positive for HER2 amplification. Which therapy is most effective?
long_questions.explanation: HER2 amplification in breast cancer is targeted by trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody.

long_questions.stem: A 40-year-old man with lung adenocarcinoma is tested for EGFR mutations. Why is this important?

options.A: Guides use of tyrosine kinase inhibitors

long_questions.explanation: EGFR mutation-positive lung cancers respond well to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., erlotinib, osimertinib).

long_questions.stem: A 50-year-old man with colorectal cancer undergoes KRAS mutation testing. Why is this performed before giving cetuximab?

options.A: Cetuximab is effective only in KRAS-mutant tumors
options.B: Cetuximab is effective only in KRAS-wild type tumors
options.C: Cetuximab is effective regardless of KRAS status
options.D: Cetuximab is contraindicated in colon cancer
options.E: Cetuximab causes severe toxicity in KRAS wild type

long_questions.explanation: Cetuximab is effective only in KRAS-wild type colorectal cancer, as KRAS mutations bypass EGFR blockade.

long_questions.stem: A 52-year-old woman with lymphoma undergoes CAR T-cell therapy. Which best describes this treatment?

options.A: Ex vivo expansion of patient’s T-cells genetically modified to target tumor antigen

long_questions.explanation: CAR T-cell therapy involves engineering patient’s T-cells to express chimeric antigen receptors that target tumor cells.

long_questions.stem: A 65-year-old man with lung cancer is found to have ALK translocation. Which therapy is indicated?
long_questions.explanation: ALK rearrangements in lung cancer are treated with ALK inhibitors such as crizotinib.

long_questions.stem: A 68-year-old woman with breast cancer undergoes pharmacogenomic testing. CYP2D6 polymorphisms affect metabolism of which drug?
long_questions.explanation: Tamoxifen is metabolized to its active form by CYP2D6. Poor metabolizers may not benefit fully from therapy.

long_questions.stem: A 62-year-old woman with melanoma undergoes BRAF mutation testing. Which drug is indicated if V600E mutation is present?
long_questions.explanation: Vemurafenib targets BRAF V600E mutations in melanoma.

long_questions.stem: A 55-year-old man with pancreatic cancer undergoes testing for mismatch repair deficiency. Why is this clinically relevant?
long_questions.explanation: Mismatch repair-deficient tumors are hypermutated and respond well to PD-1 immune checkpoint inhibitors.

long_questions.stem: A 60-year-old man with AML undergoes FLT3 mutation testing. Which therapy is effective against FLT3-mutated AML?
long_questions.explanation: FLT3 mutations in AML are targeted with tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as midostaurin.

long_questions.stem: A 70-year-old woman with breast cancer is evaluated for CYP2C9 polymorphisms before starting warfarin. This illustrates which principle of personalized medicine?
long_questions.explanation: CYP2C9 polymorphisms affect warfarin metabolism, demonstrating pharmacogenomics in therapy adjustment.

long_questions.stem: A 66-year-old man with glioblastoma receives tumor sequencing that identifies MGMT promoter methylation. Why is this important?
long_questions.explanation: MGMT methylation silences DNA repair, making glioblastomas more sensitive to alkylating agents like temozolomide.

long_questions.stem: A 50-year-old man with colon cancer has DPYD gene mutation. What is the clinical significance?
long_questions.explanation: DPYD mutations impair 5-FU metabolism, causing severe toxicity.

long_questions.stem: A 68-year-old man with prostate cancer undergoes AR-V7 mutation testing. Why is this clinically relevant?

options.A: Predicts resistance to androgen receptor inhibitors

long_questions.explanation: AR-V7 mutations confer resistance to androgen receptor inhibitors like enzalutamide and abiraterone.

long_questions.stem: A 72-year-old woman with pancreatic cancer undergoes next-generation sequencing. STK11 mutation is identified. Why is this significant?
long_questions.explanation: STK11 mutations predict resistance to immunotherapy in pancreatic and lung cancers.

long_questions.explanation: Relatives of patients with known mutations should undergo genetic counseling and testing at appropriate age.

long_questions.explanation: VHL syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
